Award.AwardTitle: A Signaling Pathway that Couples Spore Formation to the Completion of Meiosis in S. Cerevisiae.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Meiosis is the cell division program that produces haploids from diploids. The completion of meiosis is coupled to differentiation programs that generate gametes. This project will use sporulation in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, as a model system to study signaling pathways that couple gamete formation to the completion of meiosis. Smk1 is a meiosis-specific MAPK that controls the post-meiotic program of spore formation. Smk1 is activated by phosphorylation as meiosis is being completed by the CDK activating kinase, Cak1. A meiosis-specific targeting-subunit of the anaphase promoting complex (APC) ubiquitin-ligase named Ama1 regulates the Cak1/Smk1 reaction. In addition, Ssp2, a meiosis-specific protein of unknown biochemical function is required for Smk1 activation. Collectively, these findings indicate that Ama1-dependent proteolysis of an unidentified inhibitor protein, and the association of Ssp2, control the activation of Smk1 by Cak1. One aim of this project is to establish how Cak1 and Ssp2 activate Smk1. A second aim is to identify the inhibitor of Smk1 that is targeted for destruction by Ama1 and elucidate how this inhibitor controls Smk1 activation. Most of the proteins studied in this project are evolutionarily conserved. It is therefore likely that the research will generate testable hypotheses for how meiosis and gamete formation are coupled in other organisms. As such, these studies will accelerate the pace of research on gametogenesis in a broad range of organisms including other microorganisms, plants, and animals.

Broader impact:
The project provides an outstanding opportunity to train pre-doctoral students in hypothesis-driven research. To increase the impact at the undergraduate level, the principal investigator will partner with an educator at Rosemont College who is interested in studying meiotic regulation in yeast and involving talented undergraduates in the process of scientific discovery. This partnership integrates educational objectives with the research activities of this laboratory by promoting interaction between educators, researchers, predoctoral trainees, and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mitogen activated protein kinases (MAPKs) are signal transducing enzymes found in animals, plants, fungi as well as most single celled eukaryotes. MAPKs control responses to extracellular signals by phosphorylating downstream regulatory targets. The signals that activate MAPKs are varied, ranging from osmotic shock, to developmental cues, to mitogens and molecules that induce programmed cell death. MAPKs are activated by phosphorylation of an activation-loop threonine (T) and tyrosine (Y) by evolutionarily conserved kinase cascades (canonical MAPK signaling). MAPKs can also be activated by non-canonical mechanisms. These alternative mechanisms can involve kinases outside of the MAPK kinase family and can also involve self-activation of the MAPK (autophosphorylation).

 

In background data for the original grant application we described our discovery of a meiosis-specific MAPK in budding yeast, named Smk1. We described genetic studies leading to the identification of an atypical protein kinase named Cak1, a protein of unknown function namd Ssp2, and an E3 ubiquitin-ligase named Ama1 as regulators of Smk1. Based on these data we hypothesized that Smk1 is activated in a non-canonical pathway. We proposed to test this hypothesis by: Goal 1- Elucidating how Cak1 and Ssp2 activate Smk1, and Goal 2- Identifying the target of Ama1 that negatively regulates Smk1 signaling and elucidating how it regulates Smk1.

 

We accomplished the goals of the grant. These findings have defined an entirely new pathway that can activate MAPK. This novel pathway delivers a pulse of activated MAPK to a specific location in a cell at a defined developmental interval and can therefore be viewed as an “on-time delivery system” for depositing activated MAPK at a specific subcellular address. As such, this mechanism is especially well suited for controlling cellular differentiation programs.

 

Transcriptional cascades control most differentiation programs. Meiotic development in yeast (sporulation) is no exception. The transcriptional program of sporulation is well studied and provides an excellent model system for studying transcriptional cascades and protein kinase signaling. SMK1 is a tightly regulated sporulation-specific gene that is expressed as the meiotic divisions are taking place (a so-called “middle” meiotic gene).

 

The work supported by this grant showed that the CDK activating kinase, Cak1 phosphorylates the T-residue in Smk1’s activation loop as Smk1 is produced during meiosis I. This generates a partially activated kinase that controls early steps in spore morphogenesis. SSP2 is a sporulation-specific gene that is transcribed during the same stage as SMK1. However, SSP2 mRNA is held inactive until meiotic chromosome segregation is being completed. SSP2 mRNA is translationally induced at anaphase II, generating a burst of Ssp2 protein. During this interval, a double membraneous structure termed the prospore membrane (PSM) is growing around each of the 4 haploid meiotic products. The PSMs pinch off in a cytokinetic event that produces 4 cells within the mother cell.  Ssp2 is targeted to the PSM by its amino-terminal region. Simultaneously, SMK1 mRNA is also translated at the PSM. The carboxy-terminal region of Ssp2 engages the newly translated Smk1 and activates the intramolecular autophosphorylation of Smk1’s activation-loop Y-residue (see Fig. 1). This is the location where Smk1 controls spore morphogenesis (spore walls are assembled between and around the PSM). The role of the Ama1 E3 ubiquitin ligase is to antagonize Ssp2.
